This challenge can be solved through static analysis, but I found the decompilation to be a bit annoying to read, so I used a debugger instead.

Load up the executable into x64dbg and search for strings. Follow the â€œenter license key:â€ string to find the main method. At one point in the function there are three comparisons, alongside their corresponding jumps, in quick succession. The innermost jump breaks out of the loop that keeps asking for input when itâ€™s wrong. The first condition checks if the length of the input is equal to 5, the second checks if the first four characters are equal to 0x30343132, and the third one if the final character is equal to â€˜1â€™. Giving â€œ04121â€ as the input to the program wonâ€™t work because the data has been formatted in Little Endian, this means that we have to reverse the first part of the input. If we pass â€œ21401â€ as input to the program we will get a â€œCorrect Keyâ€ message.

Have a great day :) github.com/johnnnathan
